title: Who was the very first Christian believer in the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: There wasn’t really one, single “very first Christian”. The Church, as an entity, came into being at Pentecost, after Jesus’ ascension when his disciples were waiting for a sign to begin their ministry. The Holy Spirit descended on them, and that was the birth of the Church. Being as the Church didn’t exist up until that point, I think it would only be fair to say that neither did Christianity, as the Church—by definition—consists of the global community of believers in Christ. Before that point, many theologians consider Christ’s following to be a unique branch within Judaism, but not a distinct religion itself. Now, one could argue that belief in Jesus—rather than being a part of the New Testament era Church—would be the standard by which we define who the “very first Christian believer” was. In that case, it would probably have been either Adam or Eve. The first reference to the work Christ would do is found in Genesis 3:15 (called the protoevangelion, or the “first good news”) as a future hope built into the consequences of Adam and Eve’s original sin.

Biblically it was one of the disciples standing by the seashore when Jesus said, “Follow me.” But you see, back then it wasn't Christianity. That's a modern term for a modern religion. Back then it was Jesus, Messenger of God, speaking to those few who could receive his Message. He taught forgiveness, compassion, and the reality of the Holy Spirit. There were no rituals, no churches. No convoluted doctrines. If you want to learn more about the real relationship between Jesus, God, and Christianity you should read the New Message from God. Here is one of the relevant Revelations: Who is Jesus? - The New Message from God

That would be St. Peter (originally Simon), a Jewish fisherman who dropped everything to immediately follow Jesus when called to do so. He was undoubtedly the leader and most fervent of the 12 apostles and became the foundation of the church on earth, that is, the first Pope.
We don’t know their name, but it was very likely someone present at Jesus’ Baptism in the Jordan River. How about John the Baptizer himself? What a great time and place to be!

Adam and his wife Eve. They were told to offer sacrifice in similitude of the sacrifice Christ would make later. Adam walked and talked with God and understood the “Christian” gospel directly from the mouth of God.
